questions.question: Question 1: Which among the following is false regarding necrosis?

options.a: It is due to denaturation of protein
options.b: It is due to enzymatic digestion

questions.explanation: Necrosis is a passive process, not active. It is due to denaturation of protein and enzymatic digestion.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the correct sequence of events that occur during necrosis?
questions.explanation:
33 
Sold by @itachibot The sequence of events in necrosis is: cellular swelling  pyknosis  karyorrhexis  karyolysis Necrosis is defined as the spectrum of morphological changes that follow cell death due to the 
progressive degradative action of enzymes. Morphological changes that occur in necrosis are as follows: Cytoplasmic changes - • Increased eosinophilic staining on H&E specimens • Moth-eaten appearance of the cytoplasm - due vacuolated cytoplasmic organelles formed by 
enzymatic degradation • Glassy and homogenous cytoplasm - due to loss of glycogen in the cytoplasm Nuclear changes - • Pyknosis - nucleus first shrinks and becomes more condensed • Karyorrhexis - fragmentation of the pyknotic nucleus • Karyolysis - nucleus fades away leaving behind only the cell membrane or empty cells

questions.question:
Question 3: A 58-year-old man was admitted with sudden, substernal chest pain radiating to his left arm. 
On examination, he was diaphoretic and dyspneic with an irregular pulse. Despite 
resuscitative measures, he died within an hour of admission. Autopsy revealed the following 
gross appearance of the interventricular myocardium. Which of the following microscopic 
changes is most likely to be present? 24 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and image showing dead tissue are suggestive of myocardial 
infarction. It is characterized by coagulative necrosis. In coagulative necrosis, despite cell death, the outline and architecture of the cells are preserved 
for a few days. This is because the cell injury is mainly due to the denaturation of all proteins, 
including the enzymatic proteins. This prevents the proteolysis of the dead cells. Ultimately, these 
necrotized cells are removed by phagocytosis and the lysosomal action of the enzymes of the 
leukocytes. Examples of coagulative necrosis: • Ischemic injury in all organs, except the brain • Dry gangrene

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following is the most common cause of the following pathological change seen 
in the spleen?
questions.explanation:
The above image shows a pale, wedge-shaped area of infarction in the spleen. An infarct is a region of ischaemic necrosis resulting from the obstruction of blood flow, typically 
due to occlusion of the arterial supply or venous drainage. The most common cause of solid organ 
infarts is thromboembolism. The pattern of ischemic necrosis seen in solid organ infarction is coagulative necrosis. However, 
CNS infarctions are an exception. They cause liquefactive necrosis. 34 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A 67-year-old woman died in the hospital 3 days after she was admitted with a sudden onset 
of right-sided weakness of her body, along with slurring of speech. An autopsy showed the 
following finding in the brain. What is this pathological change in this lesion?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a stroke, which results in ischemic injury to the brain. This 
results in liquefactive necrosis. Liquefactive necrosis refers to cell death by enzymatic degradation. The brain contains microglial 
cells, which contain many enzymes. When these cells are broken down, they release these 
enzymes, resulting in liquefactive necrosis. The various types of necrosis are as follows: Type 
Example Coagulative necrosis 
Infarcts in all organs except t 
he brain Caseous necrosis 
Tuberculosis AbscessesBrain infarctWet ga 
ngrene Liquefactive necrosi 
s Fat necrosis 
Pancreatitis, Breast Fibrinoid necrosis 
VasculitisAschoff bodiesMali 
gnant hypertension

questions.question:
Question 6: The gross specimen of the pancreas from a patient who died of acute pancreatitis is shown 
below. What is it suggestive of? 26 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given specimen shows yellow nodules with areas of chalky-white deposits, which are 
suggestive of fat necrosis. Fat necrosis results from the release of activated pancreatic lipases into the substance of the 
pancreas and the peritoneal cavity. These enzymes act on surrounding tissue to release fatty acids, 
which then combine with calcium to produce grossly visible chalky-white areas (fat 
saponification). Histologic examination reveals foci of shadowy outlines of necrotic fat cells, with basophilic 
calcium deposits, surrounded by an inflammatory reaction. The various types of necrosis include: Type 
Example Coagulative necrosis 
Infarcts in all organs except t 
he brain Caseous necrosis 
Tuberculosis AbscessesBrain infarctWet ga 
ngrene Liquefactive necrosi 
s Fat necrosis 
Pancreatitis, Breast Fibrinoid necrosis 
VasculitisAschoff bodiesMali 
gnant hypertension 35 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 7: What is the type of necrosis seen in the vessel wall of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa?
questions.explanation:
Immune reactions involving blood vessels, as seen in the case of polyarteritis nodosa, usually 
show fibrinoid necrosis. Fibrinoid means fibrin-like. In some immune disorders, the antigen-antibody complexes get deposited in the blood 
vessels. These complexes result in complement activation (type III hypersensitivity) leading to cell 
injury. This leads to leakage of fibrin out of the blood vessel, giving a pinkish appearance around 
the blood vessels. Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in the following conditions: • SLE • Libman-sacks endocarditis • Arthus reaction • Serum sickness • Polyarteritis nodosa • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis • Malignant hypertension 36 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is involved in recognition and clearance of necrotic cells?
questions.explanation:
Inflammasomes are involved in the recognition and clearance of necrotic cells. Inflammasomes are involved in pyroptosis, a process of programmed cell death distinct from 
apoptosis and necrosis. This process is dependent on caspases 1, 4, and 5 and is responsible for 
killing of infected cells. It occurs in the following sequence: • Activation of inflammasome complex by infected cells • This causes activation of caspase-1 • This results in generation of IL-1, which is responsible for fever, inflammation, leukocyte 
recruitment Option B: Toll-like receptors (TLR)- recognizes molecules shared by pathogens Option C: P-selectins - an important role in the initial recruitment of WBCs at the site of 
inflammation & in platelet recruitment and aggregation at the site of injury.

questions.question:
Question 9: In cases of cell injury, all of the following are responsible for the increased eosinophilic 
staining and glassy homogenous cytoplasm except:
questions.explanation:
In cell injury, there is a loss of glycogen, which leads to a change in cytoplasmic appearance. An 
increase in glycogen particles is not a feature of cell injury. In cell injury, the following changes are seen in the cytoplasm: • Increased eosinophilic staining due to - • Increase in denatured proteins (which bind to acidic dyes like eosin) • Loss of cytoplasmic RNA (nucleic acids bind to basic dyes like hematoxylin) • Glassy, homogeneous appearance - due to loss of glycogen particles 37 
Sold by @itachibot • Moth-eaten appearance - vacuolated appearance due to enzymatic digestion of cytoplasmic 
organelles

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is a true statement about apoptosis?

options.a: There is enzymatic digestion of cellular contents
options.b: It is associated with adjacent inflammation

questions.explanation:
The plasma membrane remains intact in apoptosis. Apoptosis literally means falling-off in Greek. It is a pathway of programmed cell death. Apoptotic cells break up into fragments called apoptotic bodies. These apoptotic bodies have 
intact plasma membrane but altered structures. Hence, they are subjected to phagocytosis without 
eliciting inflammation. Necrosis is an unprogrammed form of cell death that includes: • Enzymatic digestion • Adjacent inflammation • Karyolysis

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is not an example of physiological apoptosis?

options.a: Endometrial cell break-down during menstrual cycle
options.b: Apoptosis of Müllerian structures in male fetuses
options.c: Elimination of neutrophils after an acute inflammatory response
options.d: Atrophy in parenchymal organs following duct obstruction

questions.explanation:
Atrophy in parenchymal organs after duct obstruction is a pathological cause of apoptosis. Physiological causes of apoptosis: • During embryogenesis - Müllerian inhibiting factor causing apoptosis of the Mullerian structures 
in the male fetus • Hormone-dependent apoptosis - • Endometrial cell breakdown during the menstrual cycle • Regression of the lactating breast after weaning. • Cell loss in proliferating cell populations - turnover of cells of intestinal crypt epithelium • Elimination of neutrophils after an acute inflammatory response and lymphocytes at the end of 
an immune response Pathological causes of apoptosis: • DNA damage beyond repair • Accumulation of misfolded proteins leads to endoplasmic reticulum stress • Cell injury in certain viral infections (e.g., Councilman bodies in viral hepatitis) • Pathologic atrophy after duct obstruction in parenchymal organs like pancreas, parotid gland, 
and kidneys

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is not an anti-apoptotic protein?
questions.explanation:
38 
Sold by @itachibot BAX and BAK are pro-apoptotic proteins. They get inserted into the mitochondrial membrane and result in the formation of channels. This 
allows proteins from the inner mitochondrial membrane to leak out into the cytoplasm. On the other hand, antiapoptotic proteins of the BCL2 family, like BCL-2 and BCL-XL limit the 
escape of proapoptotic mitochondrial proteins.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is not a stress sensor of apoptosis?
questions.explanation:
Smac, also known as Diablo is not a stress sensor of apoptosis. It is a proapoptotic protein that 
initiates the caspase cascade by neutralizing IAPs (physiological inhibitors of apoptosis).

questions.question: Question 14: What are apoptotic bodies made up of?
questions.explanation:
Apoptotic bodies are made up of cytoplasm with tightly packed organelles, and nuclear fragments. During apoptosis, extensive plasma membrane blebbing occurs, followed by cell fragmentation 
into apoptotic bodies by a process called budding. In apoptotic cells, phosphatidylserine, which is normally present on the inner leaflet of the plasma 
membrane, flips to the outer leaflet. Hence, it gets recognized by tissue macrophages and leads to 
phagocytosis of the apoptotic bodies. Annexin V is a marker of apoptosis.

questions.question: Question 15: Caspase cleaves proteins at:
questions.explanation:
Caspases are cysteine proteases that cleave proteins at the aspartic acid residue. Hence, the 
activation of caspases plays a key role in the process of apoptosis. 39 
Sold by @itachibot The activation of caspases depends on a finely tuned balance between production of pro- and 
anti-apoptotic proteins. Two distinct pathways converge on caspase activation: • The mitochondrial (intrinsic) pathway • The death receptor (extrinsic) pathway

questions.question: Question 16: What is the function of FLIP protein in the pathway of apoptosis?
questions.explanation:
FLIP is a cellular protein that inhibits the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis. It is a caspase antagonist that inhibits the activation of caspases involved in the extrinsic or death 
receptor pathway. Some viruses produce homologs of this protein. This may play a role in keeping 
infected cells alive. There are two pathways that can lead to caspase activation and cause apoptosis of the cell. APAF-1 - Apoptotic peptidase activating factor-1 TNF - Tumor necrosis factor Death receptororextrinsicpat

Question 17: 29 
Sold by @itachibot Both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are seen in:
questions.explanation:

questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following pathological changes is represented by the marked structure seen on 
histopathology of a liver specimen?
questions.explanation:
The above histopathological image shows Councilman or acidophil bodies. They represent 
hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis. Councilman bodies are commonly seen in acute viral hepatitis.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following features is not true about necroptosis?

options.a: It is a form of programmed cell death

questions.explanation:
Caspase activation does not occur in necroptosis. It is a caspase-independent form of programmed 
cell death. 42 
Sold by @itachibot Necroptosis is a programmed form of necrosis (which is normally an unprogrammed process). 
Though the activation of this pathway is similar to apoptosis, there is no activation of caspases, 
which is an important part of apoptosis. Necroptosis is triggered by the activation of TNFR1 by TNF-. This induces the recruitment of 
RIP1 and RIP3 kinase and the formation of a necrosome. The necrosome reduces cellular ATP 
levels. Necroptosis occurs in the following conditions: • Pathological - ischemic brain injury, neurodegenerative diseases, viral infections • Physiological - formation of the mammalian bone growth plate The following table lists the differences between apoptosis and necroptosis: Feature 
Apoptosis 
Necroptosis Induction stimuli 
Oxidative stress, death recept

questions.question: Question 20: All of the following are true about pyroptosis except:

options.b: There is loss of membrane integrity
options.c: It is a form of programmed cell death

questions.explanation:
Caspases 1, 4, and 5 are involved in pyroptosis, not caspase 8. Pyroptosis is a form of programmed cell death that is different from apoptosis and necrosis. It is 
involved in the clearance of necrotic and microbe-infected cells. It occurs in the following 
sequence: • Activation of the inflammasome complex • Activation of caspase-1 • Generation of IL-1 - results in fever, inflammation, leukocyte recruitment Pyroptosis differs from apoptosis by the following features: • There is cellular swelling • There is loss of cell membrane integrity • It is associated with inflammation • Caspases 1, 4, and 5 are involved 43 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 21: During the autopsy of a 90-year-old woman, a normal-looking liver was noted. The following 
microscopic appearance of hepatocytes was noted. Which of the following cellular 
mechanisms is likely responsible for this finding?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows brownish lipofuscin granules within the liver cells. It is composed of 
lipid-containing residues of lysosomal digestion that are formed due to autophagocytosis. Lipofuscin is a wear-and-tear pigment that is due to free radical injury to the tissue. It is 
prominent in the liver and heart of aging patients or patients with severe malnutrition and cancer 
cachexia. Autophagy is a process by which the cell consumes itself. It involves the sequestration of cellular 
organelles into cytoplasmic autophagic vacuoles (autophagosomes) that fuse with lysosomes, 
resulting in the digestion of the enclosed material. It occurs in the following conditions: • As a survival mechanism during nutrient deprivation and stress conditions • Cancers, inflammatory bowel diseases, neurodegenerative disorders - due to dysregulation

questions.question:
Question 22: What is the most reliable marker for cellular autophagy? 31 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Microtubule-associated protein light chain 3 (LC3) is a reliable marker for cellular autophagy. There is increased synthesis of this molecule during autophagy. LC3 plays a role in elongation and 
closure of the autophagosomal membrane. Autophagy (self-eating) is the process in which the starved cell eats its own components in an 
attempt to reduce nutrient demand to match the supply. Option A: Atg5 protein, although associated with autophagy, is not a reliable marker as there is no 
differential expression during autophagy initiation. Option B: RIP3 (receptor associated kinase 3) is a unique kinase involved in necroptosis. Option D: Annexin V is a marker for cellular apoptosis.

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following forms of cell death is induced by lipid peroxidation?
questions.explanation:
Ferroptosis is an iron-dependent pathway of cell death that is induced by lipid peroxidation. It is triggered by an increase in membrane lipid peroxidation in response to the following signals: • Excessive intracellular levels of iron • Reactive oxygen species (ROS) This leads to a loss of selective permeability of the plasma membrane, which ultimately leads to 
cell death. Unlike necrosis, the process is regulated by specific signals and can, therefore, be 
prevented by reducing iron levels. Ferroptosis has been linked to cell death in a variety of human pathologies including: • Cancer 44 
Sold by @itachibot • Neurodegenerative diseases • Stroke Other forms of cell death that are not dependent on lipid peroxidation include: • Necroptosis or programmed necrosis - programmed cell death without caspase activation • Pyroptosis - programmed cell death that is dependent on caspases 1, 4, and 5

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following is not involved in efferocytosis?
questions.explanation:
Efferocytosis is a specialized type of phagocytosis, where apoptotic bodies are phagocytosed with 
the help of macrophages, epithelial cells, and fibroblast cells. During this process, ligands bind to the apoptotic bodies and send ‘eat me’ signals. These signals 
are recognized by receptors present on phagocytes that bind and engulf these cells.

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following diseases is not caused by an abnormal folded protein?

options.a: It is a tell-tale sign of free radical injury
options.b: It is injurious to the cell and its function
options.c: It is derived through lipid peroxidation
options.d: It can also be seen in liver of aging patients

questions.explanation:
Pompe disease is a glycogen storage disorder caused by the deficiency of lysosomal acid alpha 
glucosidase enzyme. It is not due to abnormal folded proteins. During normal protein synthesis, chaperones in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) control the 
proper folding of newly synthesized proteins. Misfolded polypeptides are ubiquitinated and 
targeted for proteolysis. Sometimes, unfolded or misfolded proteins accumulate in the ER as a result of inherited 
mutations or environmental stress. This induces a protective response called the unfolded protein 
response that increases the production of chaperones. This reduces the levels of misfolded 
proteins in the cell. However, when the accumulation of misfolded proteins overwhelms these adaptations, it results 
in ER stress which leads to the activation of caspases and, ultimately, apoptosis. Some diseases that occur due to the accumulation of abnormal folded proteins are: • Alzheimer's disease • Huntington's disease • Parkinson's disease • Prion diseases • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis • Tay-Sachs disease 45 
Sold by @itachibot HunłingtÎn atnxins 
BOD1 
Prion Çqj-ses 
Presenilin 1 a-synucleìn
